Bi-Weekly Blog
Discovery Week: The Power of Kindness
We just completed our 25th annual Discovery Week and what kept popping up was the way kindness can truly be a transformative power. We encountered it at our site visits where guests were humbled by our hosts, through the generous labour of our volunteers to make the program go, of course, in the man who initiated this amazing event, our founder JW Windland. At the link , I want to share with you some moments and actions that stood out.
Photo credit: Encounter World Religions
Other Stories
Liberalizing and Women's Rights in Saudi Arabia
Alice Evans is a fascinating researcher on women's rights who uses Big Data and cross-cultural comparison to try to determine what factors lead to fairer societies for women. This article of hers is outstanding. She makes the case that Saudi Arabia is liberalizing somewhat dramatically and that this will have implications far beyond the Arabian peninsula due to the country's impact on the larger Muslim world. I found both what she says and how she is trying to track these cultural changes really interesting. Give it a read.
Photo credit: Screenshot IMDB show web page.
Chinese Government Forcing the Removal of Religious Objects from Tibetan Homes
As the Chinese government continues to try to change Tibetan culture to fit with the desires of the state, the government is now banning certain online prayers and forcing Tibetans in some villages to remove religious objects like prayer flags from their homes. Religious freedom is always a good marker for whether freedom more broadly is protected. It is disheartening to see this relentless decades-long attempt to erase a culture.
Photo credit: Canva.com
Peel Police Shifting from Warrior Mentality to that of Guardians
Peel is a suburb of Toronto where the police chief is working hard to foster a new mentality and new methods to create a more diverse workforce that partners thoroughly with the community. I found this piece especially interesting because at Encounter, we will be holding our second annual Police Religious Literacy program at Peel's headquarters this November. The 3 day program aims at helping officers gain greater literacy about the ethno-religious communities they serve and I can see now why Peel was so receptive to hosting the event.
Photo credit: Screenshot IMDB show web page.
What's Encounter Up To?
Welcoming Workplace
(August 21) - [Closed] - Federated Cooperatives - We will explore how religious literacy can foster workplace inclusion that benefits staff productivity, happiness, and retention.
Welcoming Workplace
(August 22) - [Closed] - Indiegogo - In this session with the US-based tech company Indiegogo, we will discuss why religious literacy is so critical in today's diverse societies and how workplaces can create a sense of belonging that allows people to bring their full selves to work.
Religious Literacy and Organ Donation
(September 11-12) - [Closed] - Gift of Hope, Chicago - We will learn how different religious communities approach issues around death, dying and donation. By better understanding how these issues are understood, Gift of Hope aspires to increase the rate of donation and to save lives.
The Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
(September 16) - [Closed] - Third Age Learning - York Region - We will explore the history of the land and its two peoples to better understand the current conflict. We will attempt at different times to understand how certain issues look from different sides of the conflict.
Welcoming Workplace
(September 20) - [Closed] - Oakville Public Library -
Encounter will be presenting on religious literacy for library staff and its relevance to workplace culture and in serving the public.
Week of World Religions
(September 30 - October 4) - [ Open ] - Road Scholar - In five days, attendees will learn about 5 major religions (Islam Judaism, Hinduism, Christianity and Buddhism) through informative morning classes and afternoon interviews with leaders of these respective communities. We have offered this program many times with Road Scholar and the reviews have been excellent. Come join us!
Religion: The Big Questions
(October 22 - December 3) - [ Open ] - Beaver Valley Lifelong Learning - We will explore central questions around religion like why do some feel the presence of God or spirits while others do not; why are some countries very religious and others are not; how does religion connect to politics and influence society; and we will explore unique aspects of American religiosity. Join us!
Demystifying Hinduism
(October 23) - [Closed] - Region of Peel - Hinduism is one of the largest religions on earth and is growing rapidly in Canada. In this session, we will explore some of the basics of Hinduism, misconceptions, and how to foster inclusion in our work cultures and in interacting with the community.
Inclusion and Religious Holidays
(November 7) - [Closed] - Federated Cooperatives - We will explore how religious holidays can foster workplace inclusion that benefits staff productivity, happiness, and retention.
If you are interested in learning more about how religious literacy can impact your organization, help you support and retain your staff, and attract new customers, please reach out or visit our Workplace programs page for more information.

Privacy Preference Center When you visit any website, it may store or retrieve information on your browser, mostly in the form of cookies. This information might be about you, your preferences or your device and is mostly used to make the site work as you expect it to. Because we respect your right to privacy, you can choose not to allow some types of cookies. Click on the different category headings to find out more and change our default settings. However, blocking some types of cookies may impact your experience of the site and the services we are able to offer.

They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.    Analytics Cookies        Functional Cookies These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.       Performance Cookies These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site. All information these cookies collect is aggregated and therefore anonymous. If you do not allow these cookies we will not know when you have visited our site, and will not be able to monitor its performance.        Tracking Cookies       Advertising Cookies These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. They do not store directly personal information, but are based on uniquely identifying your browser and internet device. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
